subject: Art
title: Value Structure in Painting
description: Get the darks and lights right and the painting works â€” even if the color is off.

hook.text: Squint at any great painting until colors blur away. What remains is value: the pattern of lights and darks. If that pattern is strong, the painting works. If it's weak, no amount of beautiful color will save it.

buildup.text: Value structure: organize your painting into just 3-5 value groups. Light (sky, illuminated surfaces), mid-light, mid-dark, and dark (deepest shadows). Too many values = mud. Clear value separation = clarity and impact.

discovery.text: The squint test: squint until you can only see 3 values. If your painting reads clearly while squinting, the value structure is strong. If everything blurs into the same grayish middle value, push your darks darker and your lights lighter.

twist.text: Color gets all the attention but value does the heavy lifting: it defines form, creates depth, establishes mood, and guides the eye. You can have wrong colors with right values and the painting reads. Right colors with wrong values = broken.

climax.text: Before your next painting, do a small value study in just 3 values (dark, mid, light) using gray markers or diluted ink. This 5-minute exercise solves composition problems before you commit expensive paint and time.

punchline.text: Value is the skeleton. Color is the skin. Build the skeleton first.

quiz.question: What is the 'squint test' in painting?
options: Squinting until only 3-5 values are visible to check if the painting's light/dark structure reads clearly
